column331: Any other insights about the effectiveness of targeted sanctions at preventing mass atrocities
column334: Are you of Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish origin?
column340: Years working on the tool in government
column341: Years working on the tool out of government
column342: Is respondent willing to have their name listed?
column344: Other contacts who may be able to speak with us? List name(s) and contact info

column27: I don't think targeted sanctions have ever been used to prevent mass atrocities, because they're used in response to, not for prevention. Things need to have happened, like in the case of the Rohinga. Difficult part of prevention proving the negative. Would have it have been worse without targeted sanctions? Only honest answer is sometimes. You think about Crimia, where sanctions haven't worked, but were it not for sanctions, would they be in Kiev? Would the situation be worse? If we think about when people are preventing atrocities, people are committing atrocities not for venal reasons, but for what they view as just reasons. Not a situation in which they are as responsive to dollars and cents. A real challenge how coersive authority has positive slope of effective policy up until you begin to question the identity of perpetrator.
column28: Think about sanctions, usually financial, making a target a pariah of financial community. So the most successful US sanctions program is one we don't know about: counter narcotics, this is the most common target on our sanctions list. On top of that, the most common to get off the sanctions list were drug traffickers. Least successful is Jospeh Coney. We don't know if being sanctioned helps or hurts him. The closest the target is to the narcotics example, the more effective sanctions are. Narcotics example has actor in both legal and illegal world , financial community that's real and financial community that isn't. Actor must care about having access to the finance.  Doesn't work for targets like China or Joseph Coney who create their own financial system.
column30: if the target depends on/cares about access to international financial system
column33: Very confident on case specific basis, such as with narcotics example. If they have mesionic ferver, may be less effective. Taliban may be good example of actor who depends on financial assistance. US Dollar is biggest game in town, but if other great powers are helping as we well, sanction is more effective
column35: if the target is committing atrocities for ideological reasons
column40: if the target is a member of a great power country
column43: China is an example, but Russia is a counter example. Unclear if Russia would have stopped at Kiev without sanctions
column48: You need banks to comply, and if banks are less willing to comply, then it becomes difficult to enforce.
column129: Multilateral implementation is critical. Another issue is targeting. People who are sending Joseph Kony munitions matter, not just Kony himself. Getting targeting right is critical. Hard to decide what an off ramp looks like for target, better its clear how sanctions can be lifted. Sanctions aren't a tool of punishment but rather a tool to change behavior. Part of success of narco sanctioning is the clear off ramp.
column131: If the tool is implemented multilaterally
column136: If the tool is is implemented by economic centers
column141: if the tool targets actors providing services to atrocity perpetrators
column144: Perpetrators need people in the formal system to help them.
column146: If there is a clear off-ramp to lift sanctions on the target when the desired behavior change is complete
column149: Case dependent but I know as a matter of human biology that if you end up on a list you can't get off of, there is no incentive to change behavior
column154: Is there a military component? There are ways to make it more painful, more difficult for perpetrators to continue
column332: There are times when sanctions just don’t work. Sanctions have become somewhat of a policy crutch and that’s a problem. China and maybe Russia are cases when sanctions aren’t the right tool, or the type of sanction doesn’t work.

column28: Linkages to the formal financial sector. Depriving them of access in order to use leverage. Linkage to bad actors.
column38: Commitment, resolve, and credibility in the use of sanctions; if you also have CRC in broader foreign policy toolkit, that matters too. If you're going to use sanctions in Burma and you also have diplomatic work to back it up, going to have better success. That doesn't always mean you're going to be successful, but increases the likelihood.
column134: Sanctions are not the only thing being used, you need a real comprehensive effort. US government has to be on the same page for sanctions to be effective.
column139: If you can mobilize the entire international community, especially the UN, you're doing something right.
column141: Intelligence collection: Sanctions are based on good intelligence
column144: You need to identify the right targets. Sanctions are based on good intelligence about perpetrators. It's a factor sometimes, but not a factor all the time especially when, e.g., it's obvious that Assad is targeting hospitals.
column149: Example of Syria. You can put sanctions on the jurisdiction of Syria, and that's going to be effective in implementing sanctions against specific leaders, but you have to, for example, do the humanitarian carveouts well because you need to balance those priorities. The fact that there wasn't that balance was an important part of the Oil for Food crisis in Iraq in the 1990s. Pressured Saddam but also harmed the people of Iraq. Unintended consequences are managed. Need to be able to manage downstream effects of the tool. For example, not going to have a lot of consequences if you're targeting Burmese generals, but if you're targeting the military that's going to have a lot of downstream consequences. Want to target the main guy but not the people you're trying to help.
column332: Bottom line is that sanctions may not be effective a lot of the time. The idea is that imposing sanctions in one place can prevent bad behavior in one place and then not in others. Characteristics of mass atrocities don't fit that well where most sanctions are applicable. See that in Syria where sanctions are effective in policy but not in preventing mass atrocities, because (1) Russia counterbalances effects of sanctions and (2) Assad has CW program that he uses with abandon. Relying too much on sanctions as an atrocity prevention tool is misplaced. Need continued governance support, especially from Western rules-based international order, to prevent these things from happening. If you have that, would that have fixed it? Maybe not, but you have to do something. On Burma, would have had to have government paying attention. Sanctions are useful but not everything.

column30: Identifiable group of individuals responsible for atrocities / perpetrators
column35: Access to the international financial system
column146: Clear off-ramp / process for removal of sanctions
column151: Sanctions are part of a larger AP strategy
column336: White House,State Department,US Mission to the UN

column30: Target has ties to the international financial system
column33: Target has ties to the international financial system: The extent to which the targets of the sanctions have financial interests or ties to the international financial system and/or the United States. In order for sanctions to factor into the decision making of perpetrators of mass atrocities, they have to feel like they have something to lose. Sanctions are intended to incentivize change in behavior. In order to incentivize, targeted sanctions need to be meaningful, have an impact financially, restrict someone in their family to travel to the U.S. You have to factor into the calculations of the perpetrators. Needs to be a financial stake for them to be affected by those sanctions. What has been true across the board, does the person(s) responsible for atrocities have something to lose financially or otherwise. Fundamentally that’s it. Ties to the financial system - more likely. Moderately confident in that judgment.
column38: Agrees this is an important factor. High level of commitment makes it more likely. Very confident.
column131: The sanctions are network sanctions (i.e., they target a wide swath of targets associated with the primary perpetrator) that happen synchronously
column134: Network sanctions that include related individuals and the companies they own/control. The ability to have a wide swath of targets associated with the primary perpetrator of mass atrocities. And the ability of those sanctions to happen in a synchronized way. Network sanctions that happen synchronously to confirm: yes. More likely. Very confident.
column139: International coordination among allies, when they're done in conjunction with actions taken by other governments. More likely. Very confident.
column141: Clear communication about red lines after which point the sanctions will be implemented
column144: Clearly communicating redlines before sanctions are deployed, making clear of the consequence of sanctions before atrocities are committed. Sanctions should not be reactive. They should be used as part of an established strategy of foreign policy that clearly explains what the redlines are and the consequences. Doesn't mean you tell the sanctions targets who/when there will be sanctions, but clearly articulates consequences. More likely. Very confident.
column146: Clear communication about off-ramps after which point the sanctions will be lifted
column149: In order for sanctions to be effective, there needs to be an understanding that they are not permanent. If there is a change in behavior, further atrocities/violence are withheld, there is an off-ramp to being subjected to sanctions. More likely. Somewhat confident.

column27: What do you mean by succeed? It’s a very specific issue in the sanctions world, do they work, do they succeed. They only ever work when there is a clear policy objective and support for that objective by way of a diplomatic process. I believe they almost never directly change behavior or on their own they never succeed in stopping atrocities. They contribute to the policy framework to stop atrocities. Sanctions on their own, if mass killing is going on in Burma, South Sudan, wherever, sanctions alone will not work and can’t work. It's challenging to say, of course I think they fail if done poorly.   Kyra: what context/design allow them to work better (rephrased question), overall what would you say their success has been in lowering (preventing or mitigating) the risk of mass atrocities? I would say sometimes, the middle of the road answer.
column30: There is an ongoing diplomatic process intended to resolve the conflict
column33: Diplomatic processes with whoever the actors are on the ground. Sanctions are better when they bring actors perpetrating atrocities to the table (perpetrators, their proxies, whatever it is) some framework when there is going to be negotiation. Without diplomatic process, sanctions simply by the force they bring are unlikely to change the situation. Have had conversations with diplomats who don't understand what sanctions are, or understand what they were in the context of 1990s Iraq but not now.
column35: Target has ties to the international financial system
column38: Link factor between the United States and the context on the ground is some kind of economic activity, there is some kind of business activity. Perpetrators and their proxies are engaged in some kind of activity that is vulnerable to sanctions. That economic activity involves transactions in USD/euros or something in the international system so that if the sanctions are imposed they can actually be enforced. Somewhat confident, you can have an entity involved in the financial system-- if they are connected to the financial system, they probably understand how to hide themselves/start a new company. Sanctions have to stay on top of who is designated. Often they're good at initial targeting, but six months later those actors are back and have several new companies. That's a slightly different factor. This is an important piece of the puzzle.
column40: Targets are key actors in systems that are perpetuating mass atrocities
column43: If the targets are key actors in the system that are perpetrating mass atrocities, they don't have to be commanders/or people committing mass atrocities, they need to be pieces of the puzzle/key to the system even if they are not necessarily directly responsible for the atrocities. If we go after the right people and they feel pressure. Usually they are politically sensitive.
column48: Clear targets and clear information about those targets that allows for the targeting of meaningful/relevant actors. Number of failed examples where people who were targeted were not particularly relevant to the atrocities themselves or had no financial standing that made an effect. Those always fail. Do you have a clear sense of who you want to target and do you have enough intelligence so that the banks will actually be able to enforce them? Good intelligence about the subjects. Do we have a full picture of their business network? Good intelligence and willingness to use it.
column53: Great deal of resources and commitment, that's a version of that.
column131: The sanctions serve a clear policy objective
column134: There has to be a set of policy objectives that the sanctions are working towards. Sanctions serve a clear policy objective, rather than “have” a clear policy objective. Policy comes first, sanctions are the tool.
column139: Either in USG or whatever broader coalition we’re working with-- I do believe sanctions are better when multilateral. The US is usually more aggressive with sanctions than anywhere else. I don't think sanctions have to be multilateral. There needs to be a policy framework. In the literature, you see sanctions as a tool. Can only be a tool if there is a policy framework in support of it. The context has to be a multifaceted policy framework in which sanctions are clearly designed to support an element of it. A lot of people put multilateralism as essential. At best, somewhat important.
column141: Multiple types of sanctions are used
column144: Targeted sanctions tend to mean putting individuals and companies on the list administered by OFAC and maybe align with visa bans by State Department. Sanctions tend to be more useful when a sort of broader categories of sanctions is available, whether that is commerce-level restrictions, relates to USAID work, other kinds of business-related sanctions if we have something besides just putting people on list of freezing assets, that is an important contextual element that will determine whether sanctions work.
column146: Clear communication from OFAC to banks about what the sanctions are and how to implement the sanctions
column149: Clarity for implementation, related to intelligence point a little bit. Sanctions are mostly implemented by banks, they are the main enforcement driver. From time to time, sanctions are developed that aren't clear. There are other forms of targeted sanctions (stopping certain actions/relations), if they are not clear then banks won't know how to implement them. Policymakers in a complex environment may get detached from reality. Clarity for implementation/enforcement. Clarify: Clear instructions, sanctions are clear on their face. When the US imposed sanctions at the end of 2020 on China because of its activities in Hong Kong, it caused chaos in the banking sector, and the government issuing them wasn't implementable without much more guidance. OFAC had an FAQ page about the sanctions, issued a lot (the better the sanctions, the less FAQs). They only provide guidance through FAQs, they used to have a different range of options for issuing guidance. The more FAQs, the less likely banks know what they're supposed to do or stop. Important actor. A lot of banks would say there are times banks can’t be sure they are implementing sanctions because of lack of communication with OFAC. Situations more complicated tend to be Russia, China, where there's a lot of complicated business transactions going on. When talking about mass atrocities, probably less likely complicated business going on. Burma, one example, oil companies have been confused with what OFAC is doing. It can happen, probably worth flagging as a design factor. Both a complicated context and OFAC doing a bad job communicating-- OFAC often doesn’t want to be clear and wants to be vague in the interest of stopping more transactions, not always, but sometimes. Vagueness leaves everyone befuddled.
column232: The sanctions are aggressively enforced through penalties (on American companies) for violating the sanctions
column235: One that comes to mind, enforcement. What I’ve talked about mostly is about the implementation side (do we have enough intelligence about potential targets, etc). The flip side is the enforcement piece. Over time, especially in the case of mass atrocities, there is a much shorter time lens applied. Talking about Iran, Russia, Cuba-- you’re looking at decades. Idea of enforcement, are you issuing penalties against foreign/American actors/companies for violating the sanctions? If you don't have an enforcement approach, it can weaken effectiveness because people think they can violate without getting caught. OFAC has limited enforcement division; most information comes from people self-reporting violations rather than OFAC finding them. In the case of mass atrocities, impending or ongoing genocide, if you want to stop now, you are less worried about long term penalties, if still talking about mass atrocities multiple years later, we lost it, I’m sure. Does sanction come with aggressive enforcement? Foreign actors facing monetary penalties will deter banks/companies. Somewhat (between somewhat and very). In the Iran case, aggressive enforcement was part of what led to the Iran-Nuclear agreement. Led to stronger implementation and brought Iran to the table, maybe an exception.

column30: Sanctions are targeting activities that are in clear violation of international norms
column35: Targets are concerned with international legitimacy
column40: Sanctions are enforced and send a strong signal that there are costs associated with that behavior
column131: There is clear communication with the targets about what behavior will result in costs
column136: The sanctions have broad enough authorities to respond to changing contexts
column141: Agencies that have expertise in targeted sanctions are leading the design and implementation of the sanctions
column151: Process for implementing sanctions is not overly complicated

column27: With the one point, if the question was asked differently: used to help prevent or raise awareness, raising awareness can be used for the global community to help go after regimes or governments or those engaged in mass atrocities. Sometimes the targeted sanctions take place to alert people of the mass atrocities, not stopping or preventing it, but maybe preventing others. Used to raise awareness of unjust activities at that time.
column30: Targeted sanctions are implemented after mass atrocities
column33: Sanctions follow bad activities such as mass atrocities, in the sense they are used to call out mass atrocities, they will be less likely to prevent since by necessity they come after. If targeted sanctions are implemented after, then they are less likely to prevent mass atrocities. Calls upon the speed in which the government can act, if the government can act quickly, you may not prevent every bit of mass atrocities, then you can prevent a lot of it.
column35: Targeted sanctions are implemented quickly amid or during mass atrocities
column38: If targeted sanctions are implemented amid or during mass atrocities, then you can prevent further mass atrocities.
column43: Yes, as long as you have the full factor: commitment is phenomenal and has a high level of impact on whether you can succeed but the other factor that I think is equally or significantly impactful is credibility. I'm going to pick on countries here in this circumstance, the UNHRC, when countries like Iran and Qatar and Russia are the ones coming on human rights or China, there may be less willingness for others to follow because they don't necessarily have the credibility in that space. Some can say the US government is the same, some administrations have less credibility than others, various politicians may, depends on whose issuing, commitment and credibility are fundamental factors.
column134: Government issuance, to the extent that it’s relevant, the moral/political/legal suasion of the government; characteristics used to make them more likely to prevent. There may be global corporations that may unknowingly help to fuel mass atrocities by allowing funding to those engaged in unjust activities. By having government moral/legal suasion, you may be able to persuade those in the private sector to not take part in unjust economic activity. Sanctions are used to alert unjust or negative activity. In some ways, the fact they signal outrage maybe makes it less likely to prevent mass atrocities because they're coming after certain atrocities that are occuring. Whole context: they are issued by the government, the fact they are issued by the government and are legal requirements makes them more likely to prevent.
column136: Targeted sanctions are implemented by a government moral suasion

column30: The mass atrocities are perpetrated by a state actor
column33: The dependence on the perpetrators (state or non state actor). Interviewed outgoing central banker from Afghanistan and discussed different points of leverage of the West, there are certain things states have access to by way of international recognition). If the target is a state actor-- hard question to answer, if action is perpetrated by state, often within a certain jurisdiction.
column35: Target has access to western financing
column38: Access to western finance (USD or other western currencies). Wealthy individuals for example who are bankrolling terrorist groups, not state actors.
column40: Target has access to illicit transnational resources like funds or goods that can be traded for hard currency
column45: The country in which MA are occurring is exposed to the international financial system
column48: How advanced the country is overall, exposure to export/import flows - clarified: Exposure to international financial system.
column50: The target is concerned about their reputation
column53: Reputational issues (whether perpetrators are susceptible to pressure). Usually used in context of the threat of sanctions, can’t clearly judge it. A rarely successful factor. Not something you can rely on. Makes the threat more likely.
column58: Sure, many countries around the world implement sanctions.
column131: The sanction targets an individual actor, as opposed to sanctions that cut off a broad set of resources (SDN vs financial)
column134: Sanctions on individual actors tend to be less effective than financial-based sanctions that cut off a broad set of resources. Financial sanctions tend to be more powerful than SDN sanctions.
column139: Multilateralized, can sanctions be diverted to another currency.
column141: The sanctions include a full blocking, as opposed to the licensing of certain activity based on ongoing contracts that the companies have to roll down
column144: Whether It is a full blocking, or are certain activities licensed.
column146: The sanctions target military activity, as opposed to financial activity
column332: Actors prove surprisingly resilient, can execute terrible things with few resources[?]. In instances where we were combatting IS sanctions matter less than military actions. In Xinjiang, political pressure does not remove their fiscal/monetary ability to act if they want to, if a decision is made, sanctions will only change [___?]. In enforcement, when sanctions are in place and activity is ongoing, sanctions enforcement and threats can be used to change behavior (example of Assad regime in Syria), second order effect became more effective than primary sanction itself.

column30: Sanctions target substantial economic base of the targeted country
column35: Target has assets denominated in US dollars that can be targeted
column40: Target has ties to the international financial system
column45: Implementer has good intelligence and economic analysis on the target
column131: Targeted sanctions are used alongside other tools (multitool)
column136: UN leads the targeted sanctions effort
column336: White House,Treasury,US Mission to the UN

column30: Sanctions target assets that the target cares about
column35: Sanctions target assets that the target cares about
column40: Sanctions include secondary sanctions on individuals or entities that might help the target
column136: Authorizations that allow the press, humanitarian, and agricultural sectors to continue to function
column146: Sanctions include clear communication about an off-ramp/exit strategy to get them off the list
column151: Clear, quick communication about the rules of the sanctions

column30: When they have a specific policy goal to prevent MA
column35: When targets are aware that the goal of the sanctions is to prevent MA
column40: When the targets care about their reputation in the international system

column28: Take one step back, talking about different things: asset controls, freezes, etc. My experience, targeted sanctions were often used to meet different policy objectives. Framing as prevention of genocides/mass atrocities… many times, the OFAC view, as a generalziation, their view has been more skeptcial of the efficacy of targeted sanctions in certain cases, often those when they are employed nominaly to prevent mass atrocities/genocide-- where there are fewer linkages to the US financial system may be useful as a signaling device. Many people at State and in the NGO community view these tools as feared so adding names to the list may be effective and there is evidence to that extent.
column30: Targets have financial ties to the US
column33: Biggest point of leverage, especially when talking about asset locking. For the practical effect: the US has leverage over targets (money in US banks, business, kids studying in US universities).
column35: Targets have family members studying in the US
column38: As a point of leverage, if those parents/relatives have their assets locked,it is a point of leverage, the biggest nexus would be to the financial system.
column134: Doesn’t just provide additional leverage but can help prevent asset flight, the more plugs by being multilateral, more successful as less room for evasion. Multilateral (EU linkages, working through UN or in some sort of multilateral context, principally with the EU in these cases is critical to ensure the sanctions have a tangible impact over the symbolic measure)
column139: Less relevant in terms of preventing atrocities, making the sanctions palpable, for local constituencies affected. Putting in place OFAC general licenses so humanitarian aid can be let in, even relevant in targeted sanctions case sometimes. To ensure the success of sanctions, need to see around these corners and have visibility for what else may be impacted.  Provisions to allow for humanitarian assistance: to avoid collateral impacts. Little bit more tenuous, relevant for preventing the atrocities themselves. If the perception locally or regionally that the sanctions are not narrowly targeted. Not just the local population, but local banking sector, will make it more likely for sanctions to be evaded. One caveat, I think it's important  the way those general licenses are implemented, often don’t work as intended, in an ideal form, yes.
column141: Sanctions are progressive (continuous ramping up of pressure)
column144: Follow through by policy makers. I saw several times in government, you have these programs, targeted sanctions programs, put in place when something hits the headlines. For example Darfur, massive blitz to add a bunch of names to sanctions list, if you are not keeping a consistent level of pressure over time, the sort of natural ebb and flow they will lose effectiveness as people learn how to evade, there needs to be a more focused follow through instead of forgetting it. Natural casualty of responding to whatever is most important that day. KF: If the sanctions are implemented consistently over time?  SK: No, I would even say something like, sanctions have to be progressive, need to ramp up the pressure to achieve the desired goal.

column27: I don't know, sometimes they are used, we don't really know, hard to know what you prevented, easier to know you had an impact on something that is ongoing.
column28: I don't think you can think about a tool in isolation. Sanctions have to be part of a much broader strategy using different elements of government power to be effective in the long term. People make the mistakes of thinking we can issue sanctions and solve the problem. One of the biggest mistakes people make is that they think they can issue a sanction, issue a press release, and walk away to the next problem. Does not work that way. I ran all this when I was at the Treasury. Often people think there is a problem, can go to the sanctions tool, and then think we have done something to solve the problem. Not thinking creatively about all the other things that would have been done had sanctions not been available. The State Department would often come to do the sanctions for symbolic reasons. Can be lazy thinking, unlikely to have an impact. People may be suffering on the ground, it has no impact and we have wiped our hands. I think it's more dangerous than not effective. Sanctions used with other tools and the discipline not to resort to that tool when we know it's not going to be effective. If you sanction someone with no connection to the financial system, people might care less, could be seen as a badge of honor when they know they can't trust you. In some places in the world, it might not be effective, so let's think about other things we can do to hold people to account. The most effective use of sanctions in the human rights form. When it all started in the 1940s, and from Rebecca Erbelding’s book, the US government was able to freeze 8 billion in 1940s USD, able to freeze massive amounts of money and keep it out of Hitler’s hand. If he had access to the money, imagine how much worse it could have been, but freezing the sanctions didn’t keep my grandparents alive, if the only thing we’re doing is freezing assets and not doing other things that could have helped save many other people from being slaughtered.
column30: Targets have connections to the US/international financial system / financial system of the implementer
column33: First and foremost, it has to be targeted to an individual and entity that have some connection to the US financial system, with some exceptions. Sometimes not having a connection may provide victims some hope that somebody is watching and paying attention. Human rights activists in Myanmar said when Burma sanctions were issued, it gave them hope someone was paying attention. The problem, can't just be  sanctions, needs to be much more. If it is a US sanction, there has to be some touchpoint which may vary.
column35: Sanctions target assets people care about (reputation, network, family)
column38: Have to use it to target things that people actually care about, such that if you listed it, it could change their behavior. You have bad actors, deny them access to their assets which they would use to do bad things. May not change their behavior, but at least they don't have access to those assets to do really bad things. Use it to change their behavior, so targeting things that will have an impact. Sometimes network sanctions. Sometimes people care about their international reputation, sometimes they care about sending their kids to the US, etc. High confidence in that statement, not high confidence it is going to work, it has a shot at working, high confidence. Not stopping at the individual, but finding their assets, things they are attached to, 50% or more ownership or control. By operation of law, anything that the person, any entity a sanctioned individual has 50% ownership of and or control of, is also sanctioned, even if the entity is not named on the SBN list. However, many people don’t know, banks don't necessarily know. The more you can do to name those agencies, the more effective you will be in the long run. Series of sanctions related to Hezbollah, sanctioned individuals and the fishing companies, etc. Contingent on what motivates the person.
column40: Implementer has good information about the motivation / priorities of the target
column43: ave to understand what their motivation is, going to be different for different people. Sometimes it's the threat of sanctions. Most important in the beginning, whose behavior you are trying to change and what are the motivations that will have the latest ability to influence because of the actions you take. May have a dictator who you are not going to change, a group of people around that figure you might be able to change, which might lead to human rights change. The context, the type of atrocity, the region, etc.
column45: Sanctions are part of a longer-term AP strategy
column48: Have to think about each target and how it fits into a larger, longer term strategy.
column50: Implementers estimate the impact of sanctions prior to implementation
column53: Impact and collaboration, impact is super important because of all the things I have been talking about. Before we take an action, we should assess what we think the impact would be, would have some analysts do it, hard to judge ourselves to check/assess impact, that can make the group better. Combination of all those sorts of things and I'm sure many more.
column55: Sanctions are recalibrated based on assessment of lessons learned from past sanctions
column58: Need to estimate impact after the fact and calibrate strategy in that program or other programs accordingly.
column131: Multi-tool, sanctions implemented alongside other tools.
column136: The sanctions rely on evidence from NGOs
column139: NGOs in particular, really effective in providing useful information to the Treasury and others on targeted sanctions, some NGOs have been extremely useful targeted information about targeted sanctions. Most useful relationships, when they are able to bring evidence.
column141: Significant staff dedicated to HR are committed to the sanctions programs
column144: Have to have the resources, dedicated resources, dedicated human beings, intelligence, all of that stuff, need dedicated resources, if you don't have someone with their foot on it, those resources can easily get switched to other priorities. KF: will loop into commitment SM: not just commitment, but the actual people are maybe the most important. Without people working on these programs..

column27: Almost unanswerable. If someone doesn't commit a mass atrocity, are we going to say it was because of sanctions, are we going to say it's sanctions or because they weren't as evil as we thought. I don't know. This is something we should do. For people who commit mass atrocity, whatever consequence we impose, we should do it, because it might deter something in the future. People who commit mass atrocities now, they know the US even with a powerful military is not likely to prevent it militarily. The level of our deterrence is not as great as we would like. We need to increase it. I would hate for the notion that some professor says it isn't effective so therefore we should not do it. This is worth doing, we're talking about saving lots of lives. I would do it even if we couldn’t prove it would be effective. That’s my view. Are we going to send our military into Myanmar, we’re not, so we should do whatever we can do to create whatever deterrence we can create.
column30: Target cares about its reputation and ability to operate in the international system
column33: his Is the hardest question of all. Probably thousands of contextual factors. What makes targeted sanctions most useful: do you have a target (regime or set of individuals), the extent that target wants to be integrated into the outside world. If the target has a need or desire to be connected to the outside world. Experienced by the success of visa sanctions in the DOJ, leaders of the regime wanted to send their kids to the US. The extent that it's North Korea, it's harder, because there's no desire to be integrated.  	KF: if the target cares about reputation? 	SL: Reputation is part of it; their ability to operate, reputation, ability to travel, financial  connections.
column35: Target has the power and discretion to change the conduct/commission of mass atrocities
column38: You have to choose your target for that context. We see now, targeting individuals that have no discretion anyways, functionaries in a regime where they have no discretion, that limits the effectiveness. Does the target have the capability to change what you want changed? In the Uyghur situation, does the target have the discretion to make a change in the conduct. Going after the police chief, that person doesn't have the discretion. That would be a different outcome: condemnation rather than conduct. If targeting those that have the ability to change the conduct. Makes a difference, you’re talking about the worst people.
column40: Clear communication about when the sanctions would be lifted or about red lines after which the sanctions will not be lifted
column43: In what circumstances are you willing to lift the sanctions? Suppose there’s an actual mass atrocity that you think is going to continue and you impose targeted sanctions and they stop, will you lift the targeted sanctions because they stopped killing people. Probably not. What is it you are trying to get at? There’s something to declare inappropriateness and condemning behavior, but what are you trying to achieve? Behavior change? A deterrent for someone else? That's a policy decision folks will make. 	More likely. Hard to point to historical examples of that working, but makes it more likely  to prevent. Argument can be made that it’s about preventing the next one: creating deterrence. Main policy recommendation: Create a framework; if you cross this line, there will be massive and consequential sanctions on those responsible. If you get people in advance to go along with that coalition. We don’t have the same agreement that we have around terrorism. That if you commit a mass atrocity, something really terrible is going to happen: Sanctions imposed and private sector on board .. to build up in advance the deterrence is important.  Once that happens, it’s hard to implement sanctions and then lift the sanctions once mass atrocities stopped.  When I was at Treasury, I worked with the Museum to create a framework for deterrence. Syria experience mattered to a lot of people. Good idea to create a system for deterrence in advance, or in a specific situation. Can be contextualized to one particular incidence.
column45: Commitment - the US prioritizes these sanctions
column48: I guess I do (agree with commitment as an important factor). May have thought about it differently. The United States as a sanctioning body can make any sanction stick if they decide they want it to stick. The question is where it falls on the list of priorities. If the United States sanctions 50 things and a lot of it doesn't get the same reinforcement or acceleration. The experience with Iran, they knew we cared and we had the backing all the way up to the President, that's what you need. You need to say that important enough, can make everything a high priority. How high it is as a priority.
column131: Private sector participates in a multilateral coalition that implements the sanctions
column134: Most important to build a coalition in advance, may not be the UN for obvious reasons. Could build a coalition anyways. You got this as something with which big corporations view as part of their due diligence on appropriate business partners. Not just banks, but corporations in general. Should be part of what they're all looking at. Part of looking at a supply chain. Making sure you're not associated with mass atrocities.  Multilateralism, but not just about the government, but about the private sector. We should not ignore the ability of international businesses to do these things. That is what made Iran sanctions work, we got them to do things they didn't have to do by law.  This is the one that for practitioners, commentators, researchers, it's harder to analyze and think about, it's undervalued. Undervalued as a factor. Get in the habit of talking to governments. Sanction officials fly around the world and talk to counterparts. Making a mistake, should be flying around the world and talking to CEOs. Multilateralize these things but go to the people who are making these decisions.
column136: Sanctions target assets or other issues (e.g. travel) that the targets care about
column139: Aiming for the pain point of the particular target. The example I had wasn’t about mass atrocities. The real pressure point for this government was visas to the United States. Nothing to do with mass atrocities: when designing sanctions, what's likely to persuade them. For this country it was visa sanctions and they changed their policies. For small countries, OFAC at the Treasury isn’t always the right tool. Depends on what the target is. If the sanctions target the pain point of a particular target (not assets as implies money). We should not underestimate the power of targeting what the people in these countries want, e.g., to send their kids to America, if you can get people on the Interpol list, get Europe to get along with you. The elite want to get out, they want their kids and family to get out.
column332: Trying to lay the groundwork. It’s great we have warning signs, but we should be trying to make this a part of the general conversation. We should be trying to get a framework in place so people realize this is something [referring to targeted sanctions] that happens when there is mass atrocity. Creating a general framework for businesses in the private sector in general and not just when there are warnings for specific cases.   I think it's very hard to reverse sanctions after the atrocities occur even if it stops, might make it more effective, but not really going to stop. I think that's fine. The hardest possible question: are you really going to give an incentive for someone to stop an atrocity? I haven't done a detailed analysis. What we have done with Sudan, did we reverse sanctions on people we felt had been complicit? I don't know the answer to that, but there are people who would, would  be worth analyzing.  Very hard to come up with a formula for what to do in advance. Thousands of contextual factors, trying to identify them is difficult. It is difficult, but coming up with a framework of what should happen in advance is valuable, have to adjust to the context whatever it is. It is impossible to predict.    Perpetrators of mass atrocities are pretty bad, hard targets. We should do these things alongside other things. How likely they are to work, going to be hard.   Syria situation, because it didn't work once, doesn’t mean it never will.

column27: Overall view, I think they are likely ineffective. They can provide a signaling effect which can be useful. There are targets that resent/are upset by being added to a sanctions list. A government that has embarked on a program of mass atrocities typically has a high commitment to that policy, not done on a whim. The domestic and political forces to overcome are huge. A more policy relevant question is the use of broad sanctions to deter mass atrocities. The only time sanctions have changed a significant policy were broad sanctions (South Africa in response to apartheird / sanctions drove Iran to come to table for nuclear deal / in Sudan, change in policy for South Sudan and other key issues plaguing US-Sudan relations, not necessarily Darfur). Severe limits on what targeted sanctions can achieve if looking at major government policy you seek to change.   LW clarification: broader sanctions are effective because there is more of an impact on domestic/political context that is a stronger drive on the situation than targeted sanctions? AS: Yes, the government's I mentioned were afraid of running out of money. If they can’t provide  basic necessities and the risk of being pushed out of power. Interesting middle cases because it's a spectrum. If you sanction the largest oil entity in Iraq, responsible for 80% of revenue, considered broad sanction.
column30: Target is “plugged in”/has assets in the international system
column33: Relations between sending and receiving country-- talking about atrocities going on in Turkey, has a rocky but historically close relationship with the United States. Government officials have assets in the US, greater potential for leverage than for somewhere like Libya or Sudan. Can situate countries on that spectrum, Myanmar would be somewhere in between. Somewhere like Belarus, there would likely be a greater impact for EU sanctions. How intertwined, first thing that comes to mind. KF: If the target has assets in the implementing country/desire to travel in the implementing country.? AS: The more plugged in the individual is in the international system, wealthy Chinese officials with no assets in the United States but businesses with Singapore and India, targeted sanctions will make a big difference because you have a lot to lose and need the USD. *Likely 3rd or 4th order effect it might have in preventing mass atrocities, way you phrased it seems oversimplified, claiming too much for any sanction. These factors are drivers in terms of the impact of the sanctions. Now you can then start to extrapolate for what impactful sanctions might mean for impacting the government. *to pull back, struggle to think of incidents where targeted  have impacted ongoing atrocities or prevented the outbreak. The whole discussion is against that backdrop, a very poor if 0 track record. If that's the case, why do it at all. I do think there's value. Can't think of a case where we targeted senior officials/elites/cronies. It makes it hard to say, doing smart designations against more vulnerable targets makes it more likely to, we are talking about the entire set is unlikely to impact the outcome.
column38: Is this just one country applying targeted sanctions, or is there a coalition, is it under UNSC with broader applicability
column48: ypes of individuals listed will make a big difference. Janjaweed in Darfur, no impact since they have no assets/plans to leave. More senior/wealthy elites, potentially see greater impact. KS: If sanctions target elite/high level targets? AS: In addition to being elite, they are wealthy/business owners/own business conglomerates will be more vulnerable.
column131: Implementer targets full set of holdings and associates of the target, not including close family members
column134: king sure targeting goes towards all of the holdings of the sanctioned party.A lot of debate about going after close family members, my view is we should not, absent there is evidence they are being used to circumvent the targeting. Not an effectiveness question, not the right thing to do.
column139: he US stands alone as having tremendous credibility or generating a lot of fear that noncompliance will land companies in trouble.  KF: Included in the commitment question? AS: I think most people outside of the world of sanctions might understand commitment to mean something emotional. EU really committed to Burma, an entire building with Aung San Suu Kyi on it, the commitment was very deep, but the enforcement wasn’t meaningful.
column332: Targeting the head of state. Present thorny diplomatic situation, often considered tantamount to calling for regime change.  Another axis, on a diplomatic axis.
